page.lettertext:
fol.14r
May it please yo
r
good L. in
e conference desired by
e
Emperor
s
Ambassado
r
, wherof I made mention in my last to yo
r
L. I
should be over tedious, to recite every pointe
at passed heere
between us. But yet as muche as is materiall I thought fitt
to advertise w
t
the first oportunitie. All his speeches tended
to feele w
at
I would say to his proposall of a peace: and by me
to understand, howe her
Ma
tie
and
e
states
were affected in
e
matter. But because I woulde not feede him w
t
a frivolous
hope of knowinge
at by me, w
ch
I knewe not yet my self, I
lette him plainly understand,
at for her Ma
ties
inclination it was
unknowen unto me, and likewise of
e states I would not speake
but by conjecture. But in case he would acquaint me w
t
the
principall drift of his p
nt
Ambassade, and w
t
the qualitie of those
conditions that are intended to be offered, I would then as a
privat
privat person, and by way of communication, tell him frankely
my opinion. Upon this he protested,
at as alwaies he professed,
and his father before him,
e reformed religion, so he could not but
tender the cause of these contreys: and in
at respect would rather
suffer any miserye, then become an instrument of
e spaniard, whome
he hated from his heart, to ruine their estate. For whiche his
purpose was no other, but to deale as I requested very roundly
and sincerely, and to disclose the whole designe of this p
nt
legation
Howbeit he requested me to take it of him, as privatly spoken,
w
t
out any Co
m
ission: upon confidence onely,
at I would deale
againe as roundly in retourning my opinion. First for himself,
his p
nt
charge was no other but to negotiat w
t
e states,
at
e
rest of
e Ambassado
rs
might have licence to come hither: or if
they might not be permitted to come unto
e Hage,
at some place
should be assigned upon the frontiers, or at lest
at
ei would send
their Deputies to
Collen.
For the rest of
e Ambassado
rs
their
commission was no other, but induce the states unto a Treaty:
and
at a Treaty being admitted, they were to send againe unto
e
Empero
r
,
for some further instruction, not having yet receaved
fol.14v
any articles or matte
r
to propose unto
e states. Byt yet [he thought]
in
e ende,
e motions to be made would come to this [effect: that]
seing there was no hope, to reconcile this people to the
[King of]
Spaine
, whome by way abjuration they had exclu[ded for]
ever from the rule of these contreis, they should therefore [condescend]
to unite themselves in one w
t
the rest of
e 17 Provin[ces]
all in general to acknowledge
e Empero
r
for their S[overeign]
and after his deceasse
e heires of his body, or for f[ault of such]
heires, to make choise in his familie, of whomsoever t[hey most]
desire. He delivered this but as a plotte, not acco[rded as]
yet by the K. of Spaine but projected by great p[ersonages]
who, if the Treaty be accepted, make it easie enou[gh to]
compasse: ether by procuring a mariage between
e [Emperor]
and
e
daughter of Spaine
, and
e inheritaunce of th[ese Countries]
to be given in dowerie; or by some other suche persu[asion, as he]
was well assured, would take good effect. So that [if the right]
of
Spaine
were derived to
e Empero
r
, and suche oth[er conditions]
admitted w
t
all, as the states might indent for their [further]
securitie, there was no occasion to his understandin[g why that]
ether
e people of these Provinces, or any of their [allies,]
should stand in any doubt of
e puissance of the Sp[aniard]
As touching the premises I made him this answear. [That]
first for his owne suite, I sawe no likelihood of leave [for the]
rest of
e Commissioners to come unto
e Hage, or to [any place]
upon
e confines. They were many in nomber, and som[e of them]
they knewe by former experience, to be very ill affe[cted to the]
cause of these contreis, and not any but himself well [instructed]
in religion. By reason wherof we should alwaies [be in fear]
of their couvert proceeding, and corrupting of
e peop[le more]
over there were many respectes, for w
ch
I thought they [would]
refuse, to send any man to Collen. For
e bruite [alone of]
their sending, might cause an alteration, among
e co[mmons of]
this Contrey: and might turne to their prejudice both [in
England
]
fol.15r
and in
Fraunce:
where
e occasion of their sending would be knowen
to a fewe, but most men would imagine,
at they had yelded already
to an actual Treaty w
t
e Enemie. And if their errand were
no other but to worke this people to a Treaty, it might aswell
be perfourmed by one as by many, and assoone by their letters,
as by their presence. For they should not neede to doubt, but
at this Contrey would be foreward, if her Ma
tie
w
t
whome they
had contracted, and the
F
r
Kinge
who was greatly interessed
would assent therunto. And for my self I was persuaded,
at if the Empero
r
would endevo
r
by vertu of his Imperiall
autoritie among Christian Princes, to cause the
Pope
and
Kinge of Spaine, to w
t
drawe their forces out of France, both
e Queene and
e Kinge would presently and willingly hearken
to any Treaty, that might stand w
t
their safetie. And untill
suche time, as
at be done, it was in vaine to my thinking, to
make any motion to them or to this people. As touching
at
Project of reducing these Provinces to the Empero
rs
obedience,
being done in that order, as he had declared, by resignation of
e
Kinge, and suche couvenants accorded, as were meete to be requi-
red, as farre as I could conceave in a matter of
at moment, and
so newly proposed, it would not be rejected. But yet I thought
it would prove a tedious peece of worke. For to send first
into England and France to persuade their Ma
ties
to embrace a
Pacification: and then to use intercession w
t
the Pope and w
t
Spaine, to revoke their forces: and after to capitulat upon
e pointes of makinge over the inheritaunce of
e contrey, it
would require suche lenght of time, as I see litle cause to
expect a good issue. Againe considering howe
e Kinge
shalbe touched in honor in
e ende of so many yeares warres, and
after the consumption of so great a treasure, to be forced by a
handfull of people and by his owne Vassalls, to surrender his title
in so many Provinces, it is to be presumed, that he will use as
many shiftes to protract the time, as every light occasion shall
fol.15v
minister unto him: that if he happen to prevaile in so[me battle in]
France, he will p
nt
ly retract all these offers of the Em[pero
r
.]
To rehe rse what he replied to every part of my speech [were]
to comber yo
r
L. w
t
unnecessary matter. In
e ende h[e concluded]
that he thought as I had saide, there was nothing to [be hoped]
in dealing w
t
e states, unles England and France w[ere first]
solicited and cessation of armes procured in France. [That had]
also bin alwaies
e opinion of
e Empero
r
, who he knewe [was]
desirous to have made his motion there at first, b[ut that]
no intercession was used unto him, and of him self he [had no]
cause. For in the sending of his Commissioners to dea[le with these]
Provinces, he was moved unto it, by
e Princes of
G[ermany]
being also bounde therunto, in as muche as these contre[ys depend]
from the Empire, and were alwaies concluded in
e circle [of
Bur]
gundie
. But if
e states would be persuaded to writ[e unto the]
Empero
r
, and certefie expresslie,
at w
t
out the notice a[nd assent]
of England and France, they will not hearken to any [motion]
he did not make any doubt, but
at
e Empero
r
therupo[n would]
frame his course to their content. This is
e summe [of a]
longer conference, of w
ch
I humbly beseeche yow, to consid[er what]
is fitte to be imparted to her Ma
tie
and if any imperfec[tion be]
noted in
by
my dealing, to excuse it w
t
a worde of yo
r
h[onorable]
favor.
And so I take my humble leave. Hage Fe
b
